Problem:
Consider a system governed by the partial differential equation \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} + i\\omega u = 0\\), where \\(i\\) is the imaginary unit and \\(\\omega\\) is a constant. The impact of a Laplace transform \\(\\mathcal{L}\\{u(t, x)\\}(s)\\) is analyzed to understand its effects on the solution trajectory over variable \\(s\\).

If at time \\(t_1\\), a transformation \\(g(x) = e^{bx}\\) (where \\(b\\) is another constant) is applied as an intervention, will the final state \\(u(T, x)\\) for \\(T > t_1\\) be independent of the original transformation \\(f(x)\\)?
Explanation: Introducing \\(g(x)\\) at \\(t_1\\) adds another level of spatial transformation which interacts with the initial modification brought by \\(f(x)\\). The resulting state \\(u(T, x)\\) will be dependent on both transformations, affecting the final outcome through the compounded effect of sequential spatial changes.
